description: From Middle English rampand, rampend, present participle of rampen (“to rise by climbing, shoot up, sprout, sty, ascend”), from Old French ramper (“to creep, climb”) (see below), equivalent to ramp +‎ -and or ramp +‎ -ant. Recorded since 1382, "standing on the hind legs" (as in heraldry), later, "fierce, ravenous" (1387). Compare Scots rampand (“rampant”).

Alternatively from Middle English *rampant, from Old French rampant, the present participle of ramper (“to creep, climb”), equivalent to ramp +‎ -ant. Old French ramper derives from Frankish *rampōn, *hrampōn (“to hook, grapple, climb”), from *rampa, *hrampa (“hook, claw, talon”), from Proto-Germanic *hrempaną (“to curve, shrivel, shrink, wrinkle”).

adjectives.description: rampant (comparative more rampant, superlative most rampant)

entries.meaning: (originally) Rearing on both hind legs with the forelegs extended.
examples: The Vienna riding school displays splendid rampant movement.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) Rearing up, especially on its hind leg(s), with a foreleg raised and in profile.
examples: ‘I forget your coat of arms.’‘A human foot d’or, in a field azure; the foot crushes a serpent rampant whose fangs are imbedded in the heel.’

entries.meaning: (architecture) Tilted, said of an arch with one side higher than the other, or a vault whose two abutments are located on an inclined plane.
Unrestrained or unchecked, usually in a negative manner.
examples: Weeds are rampant in any neglected garden.

entries.meaning: Rife, or occurring widely, frequently or menacingly.
examples: There was rampant corruption in the city.

adverbs.description: rampant (comparative more rampant, superlative most rampant)

examples: Things seem to be running rampant around here lately.
